title-group.article-title: The state of e-legal deposit in France: Looking back at five years of putting new legislation into practice and envisioning the future

fn.p: Peter Stirlingis Digital Curator in the Legal Deposit Department of the National Library of France. He has worked for the digital legal deposit team at the National Library of France since 2009, where in addition to contributing to the day-to-day web archiving activity, he works on services for users of the web archives and the international activity of the team. After gaining an MA in English Literature and an MSc in Information and Library Studies, he worked for an online information portal for health professionals in the UK before moving to France to work in online information monitoring for the French National Cancer Institute. Contact: Legal Deposit Department, Bibliothèque nationale de France, T1N4 – BnF - Quai François Mauriac – 75706 Paris Cedex 13, France. Email: peter.stirling@bnf.fr

Gildas Illienis Director of the Bibliographic and Digital Information Department of the National Library of France. From 2005 until 2011 he was in charge of the digital legal deposit team at the BnF. Since 2006, he has also served as Program Officer and Treasurer of the International Internet Preservation Consortium (IIPC: www.netpreserve.org), representing this organisation in international conferences and organizing international cooperation for software development, advocacy and collection building in the field of web archiving among 40 heritage and research institutions spread on three continents (Europe, North America, Asia). A digital curator with academic background in management, political science and sociology, he has published several articles and book chapters about web archiving (collection development, usages, international cooperation). Pascal Sanzis Director of the Law, Economics and Politics Department of the National Library of France. A trained librarian with a Master’s degree in History, Pascal Sanz has occupied senior management positions in a number of French library organizations over the past 30 years. Before being appointed to the BnF in 2004, he notably served as Director of the Centre technique du livre de l’enseignement supérieur (the national conservation center for academic libraries), and Director of documentation services of the Centre national de documentation pédagogique (specialized in educational resources). As director and chief curator of the Law, Economics and Politics Department at the BnF, Pascal has carried out major conservation and digitization projects in these disciplines, including newspapers. He has also supervised the most active and pioneering curator team engaged in web archiving since the early days of e-legal deposit at BnF, starting with the first national election harvest and continuing through to the current development of born-digital collections of government publication websites, news websites, and corporate websites. This experience has placed him in a good position to reflect on the evolution and relationship of print vs. digital heritage material. Fluent in English and Spanish, Pascal is a strong advocate of international cooperation and has served in a number of strategic positions at IFLA in various sections (library statistics, research and theory, acquisitions and collection development) and as a member of IFLA governing board, professional committee and executive committee. Contact: Law, Economics and Politics Department, Bibliothèque nationale de France, T2N1 – BnF- Quai François Mauriac – 75706 Paris Cedex 13, France. Email: pascal. sanz@bnf.fr

Sophie Sepetjanis Director of the Legal Department of the National Library of France. A lawyer and a graduate in foreign languages (English, German and Spanish), Sophie Sepetjan started her career as a solicitor working for an international law firm in Paris. In 1998, she joined the BnF’s Legal Department, where she specialized in copyright and intellectual property law as applied to new technologies and digitization in the context of the BnF’s active involvement in the development of national and European digital libraries (e.g. Gallica and Europeana). She was appointed Director of the Legal Department in 2006, where she has since been responsible for overseeing all legal issues in relation with the activities and missions of the Library. Legal deposit being one of the Library’s core missions, Sophie has become an expert in this field, closely following the various revisions of the current legislation in order to introduce new provisions for e-legal deposit and web archiving into French law. Sophie actively contributes to several international legal and library organizations: since 2009, she has been a member of the Copyright Working Group of CENL (Conference of European National Libraries) and of the IFLA-CLM (IFLA Committee on Copyright and other Legal Matters).
